title: perf: use an asynchronous open function even for local files
body: The `LocalObjectReader` was relying on `open` being a synchronous function which is not a safe assumption when working with NFS filesystems.  This PR changes it to an async function.

title: perf: allow take to process multiple fragments in parallel
body: We had previously commented out a call to buffered, probably to avoid the higher order lifetime issue that appears.  However, this lifetime issue is a bug and we can work around it by collecting the futures into a vector before buffering them.

title: Move IO to separate scheduler
body:
## Motivation

Right now, our IO parallelism is choppy and inconsistent. This is essentially due to three issues: ad-hoc parallelism settings, no queuing of IO tasks, and CPU-tasks blocking IO tasks.

Right now, our IO parallelism is determined ad-hoc as we call `.buffered()` and `.buffer_unordered()` throughout the codebase. This leads to a sort of tree where we read `N` fragments in parallel, `N * M` batches in parallel (each fragment reading `M` batches in parallel), and `N * M * K` columns in parallel. Each level of parallelism is usually set as `num_cpus::get()` or `num_cpus::get() * 4`, which is sometimes adequate for machines with large CPUs but often inadequate for smaller machines. This is a very indirect way to control the amount of allowed IO parallelism, and is not consistent throughput all code paths.

The `.buffered()` calls also cause the amount of IO parallelism to vary over time. After the first round of tasks, the system must wait for the first fragment's tasks to finish before a new fragment's worth of tasks can start. This causes a sort of sawtooth pattern in IO utilization:

![image](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/assets/5488879/1707f0e1-c43f-4f4b-ba09-359c17463cd7)

In addition, we often interleave IO tasks and CPU-bound tasks. For example, while reading batches of data, we will apply filters or masks as we read. This often blocks new IO tasks from starting.

## Solution

We can move IO into a separate scheduler:

* Instead of running IO requests eagerly, we can build them up in a queue. This means we can push enough of them to ensure that the scheduler always has some IO work ready to keep it busy.
* This also can simplify implementation. At the column level and below, instead of using calls to `.buffered()`, we can simply create an entire vector of futures and use `try_join_all()` to wait for all of them to finish.
* The scheduler will control the exact number of concurrent requests, making that much easier to control directly. This will also decouple it from the number of CPUs (which it is currently tied to).
* By running the task on a separate thread / task, we ensure no CPU-bound work will block the IO work.

```
                     SCHEDULER
                     ┌─────────────────────────────────────────┐
                     │                                         │
                     │    IO QUEUE                             │
                     │   ┌─────────┬─────┬─────────┐           │
                     │   │         │     │         │           │
     get_range ──────┼───► Request │ ... │ Request │           │
         ▲           │   │         │     │         │           │
         │           │   └─────────┴─────┴─────┬───┘           │
         │           │                         │               │
         │           │                         │               │
         │           │                         │ IO TASK POOL  │
         │           │                     ┌───▼────┐          │
         │           │                     │        │          │
         └───────────┼─────────────────────┤ Future │          │
                     │                     │        │          │
                     │                     ├────────┤          │
                     │                     │        │          │
                     │                     │ Future │          │
                     │                     │        │          │
                     │                     ├────────┤          │
                     │                     │        │          │
                     │                     │ Future │          │
                     │                     │        │          │
                     │                     └────────┘          │
                     │                                         │
                     └─────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

### The right user facing knobs

There are three resources of concern here:

1. The amount of memory we can use to buffer batches
2. The number of IO requests we can make concurrently.
3. The amount of scheduling overhead.

Right now, the `{batch,fragment}_readahead}` control both (1), (2), and (3). With the scheduler, we can separate them into a more global setting `max_parallel_io`, which directly controls (2), and `{batch,fragment}_readahead`, which will control (1) and (3).

### Potential extensions

By bringing IO calls to a more central location, we can also do more intelligent management of IO. This includes:

 * [ ] https://github.com/lancedb/lance/issues/1505
 * [ ] On object stores, pre-emptively retry requests that are taking too long

title: Cache fragment metadata in-memory
body:
For Take we currently have to perform one set of IOs to read fragment metadata, and then we read the actual data.
We could significantly improve the e2e latency by caching the fragment metadata. We would also need a reliable mechanism to "warm up" this metadata cache.

and initialized local image uri arr.

Then I encoded an image extension array using:
`arr = ImageURIArray.from_uris(arrow_table["uri"]).read_uris()`

Wrote the table to Lance format.

then tried to do: `lance_dataset.take(np.random.randint(0, len(pets), 1000))`

This fails non-deterministically with:

```
In [84]: lance_dataset.take(np.random.randint(0, len(pets), 1000));
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OSError                                   Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[84], line 1
----> 1 lance_dataset.take(np.random.randint(0, len(pets), 1000));

File ~/.venv/lance/lib/python3.11/site-packages/lance/dataset.py:446, in LanceDataset.take(self, indices, columns, **kwargs)

    431
    432     Parameters
   (...)

--> 446     return pa.Table.from_batches([self._ds.take(indices, columns)])

OSError: LanceError(Arrow): Invalid argument error: Last offset 15304029 of Binary is larger than values length 15189806
```

title: chore: update arrow (to `48.0`) and datafusion (to `33.0`)
body:
### Known test failure:

Due to a change in DF where statistics are pulled even when not requested in `IndentVisitor`, the test `dataset::scanner::test::test_secondary_index_scans` fails since there's an error pulling statistics. The error corresponds to not being able to create a scalar from `FixedSizeList` (which should not be expected since a corresponding scalar exists).

**The error:**

```
This feature is not implemented: Can't create a scalar from data_type "FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: Float32, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 32)"
```

**Problematic DF Code:**

https://github.com/apache/arrow-datafusion/blob/93b21bdcd3d465ed78b610b54edf1418a47fc497/datafusion/physical-plan/src/display.rs#L263-L266

Fixes: #1694

title: fix: remove default memory cap for index training
body:
Removed hard-coded 4GB limit, as sometimes that produces errors like:

```
OSError: LanceError(IO): Resources exhausted: Failed to allocate additional 5618883160 bytes for ExternalSorter[0] with 0 bytes already allocated - maximum available is 4284481536, /rustc/79e9716c980570bfd1f666e3b16ac583f0168962/library/core/src/convert/mod.rs:716:9
```

Instead users can set this as an environment variable:

```shell
export LANCE_MEMORY_LIMIT=$((4 * 1024 * 1024 * 1024))
```

I did an environment variable for now because the indexing parameters are a mess and I don't want to refactor them yet.

Because we don't know how much memory the client machine may have, we set it to unbounded by default.

Closes #1701

title: Make shuffling RAM limit configurable
body:
When indexing large datasets, users can get an OOM error:

```
OSError: LanceError(IO): Resources exhausted: Failed to allocate additional 5618883160 bytes for ExternalSorter[0] with 0 bytes already allocated - maximum available is 4284481536, /rustc/79e9716c980570bfd1f666e3b16ac583f0168962/library/core/src/convert/mod.rs:716:9
```

This happens in Lance v0.8.19 only.

title: fix: add _rowid when `use_stats=False`
body:
When `use_stats=False`, we need to add `_rowid` to the projection if there are additional columns we need to pull. Otherwise we get:

```
ValueError: LanceError(IO): Error during planning: TakeExec requires the input plan to have a column named '_rowid'
```

title: fix: prevent stats meta from breaking old readers
body:
Older readers have a bug where they will read past the end of the file when reading the statistics metadata. Those older readers were before statistics were even used, so we don't care about them working. This commit moves the proto field so that only newer readers will pick it up.

Closes #1697

title: fix: revert stats aware scanner to fix broken files
body:
This reverts commit 04d0e88e374b827e7c5951bed2503e82b904b411.

Fixes: #1697

title: Files written by v0.8.19 aren't readable by earlier versions
body:
``` >>> ds.head(10, columns=['category']) Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in File "/Users/willjones/mambaforge/envs/lance-dev/lib/python3.10/site-packages/lance/dataset.py", line 496, in head return self.scanner(**kwargs).to_table() File "/Users/willjones/mambaforge/envs/lance-dev/lib/python3.10/site-packages/lance/dataset.py", line 1634, in to_table return self.to_reader().read_all() File "pyarrow/ipc.pxi", line 757, in pyarrow.lib.RecordBatchReader.read_all File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 91, in pyarrow.lib.check_status OSError: Io error: Execution error: External error: Execution error: LanceError(IO): failed to fill whole buffer, /Users/runner/work/lance/lance/rust/lance-core/src/io/local.rs:127:13 ```
Reproduction

Using Lance v0.8.19, Write with: ```python import string import random import pyarrow as pa import pyarrow.compute as pc import lance num_rows = 1024 * 1024 num_dims = 1536 tab = pa.table({ "id": pa.array(list(range(num_rows))), "score": pc.random(num_rows).cast(pa.float32()), "category": pa.array([random.choice(string.ascii_uppercase) for _ in range(num_rows)]), }) lance.write_dataset(tab, "test") ```

title: blog post: statistics and scanning
body:
Write a blog post covering:

* Addition of new statistics
   * How we made them more like page index than row group stats
* How we implemented it
  * Use of expression simplification + late materialization
* Role of DataFusion's expression libraries
* Relation to scalar indices
* Where they are integrated, and where they are not
  * Integrated: scans, deletion
  * TODO: scans with scalar index, prefilter

title: fix: add shutdown to async loader
body:
The loader didn't exit and was block script completion. This PR adds a context manager that ensures the async worker is closed.

Also added some comments about the difference

title: feat: add support for new and deleted data to scalar indices
body:
When we are doing a `ScalarIndexQuery` we do not need to worry about new and deleted data because the ANN search already handles deletion and won't run on new data.

When we are doing an indexed scan then we do need to worry about this.

For new data we do:

```
# indexed fragments
MATERIALIZE_INDEX -> TAKE -> UNION
# new fragments
SCAN -> FILTER -> PROJECT -> UNION
```

To handle deleted data we load the deletion vectors as part of the materialize index node.

title: LanceDataset.to_batches() scanning becomes slower for later batches
body:
When iterating over `lance.dataset` by calling [dataset.to_batches()](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/82bad305b1f1664f650a92a5ab5846b96e1e255e/python/python/lance/dataset.py#L358), the latency of yielding the same sized batches keeps increasing for later batches. I was expecting the amount of time to yield each batch to be the same.

Hi @chebbyChefNEQ , i saw this issue in the same effort of using KMeans where i recognized [Issue 1686](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/issues/1686#issue-2025183900), "Lance Dataset Iteration does not honor batch_size", which you are looking into. Thanks ! :)

title: feat: add batch buffering and async loading to torch.LanceDataset
body:
closes #1686 

buffer batches together so GPU can train more efficiently

title: Lance Dataset Iteration does not honor batch_size
body:
When using lance.torch.kmeans.KMeans, the train batch size used by the iterator does not match the batch_size given by the user.

In particular, this [line](https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/e77eabfaadb5801a3fe3d28eaec935e18fc55f61/python/python/lance/torch/kmeans.py#L199). When the lance dataset is written with a multiple `.add(batch)` where batch is of size 1,000, the chunk size returned gets upper bounded by 1,000.

Further, even if the writing is done with a batch_size of 2,000; the reading batch_size gets upper bounded by 1,024

title: Add vector index correctness tests
body: TBD

title: Support bf16 vector columns
body:
We need to be able to roundtrip bf16 vector columns.

We can remove this line to enable testing this:

https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/e77eabfaadb5801a3fe3d28eaec935e18fc55f61/python/python/tests/test_tf.py#L444

The error we get right now is:

```
pyo3_runtime.PanicException: called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: Schema { message: "Unsupported logical type: fixed_size_list:fixed_size_binary:2:6", location: Location { file: "/Users/willjones/Documents/lance/rust/lance-core/src/datatypes.rs", line: 200, column: 39 } }
```

The problem is Lance writes data types as strings, and so we need to decide a string representation here.

1. Option 1: we create a special string serialization for bfloat16.
2. Option 2: we allow fixed size list to take arbitrary child types. This would be the most flexible, but would require being able to serialize the extension type and all that of children.

title: feat: add option to pass in precomputed row_id -> ivf partiton mapping and compute partiiton on GPU
body:
This PR allows caller to pass in a precomputed `row_id -> ivf_partition` mapping. This is very helpful when the number of IVF is large and we want to rely on external mechanisms like GPU or distributed compute for computing these partitions.

Baseline:
```
[2023-12-04T18:03:19Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf::builder] IVF shuffler built
[2023-12-04T18:14:27Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf] Built IVF partitions: 722.0641s
```

This PR: (building partitons on GPU took 10 seconds)
```
[2023-12-04T17:36:55Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf] Loading precomputed partitions from file: 3ac9988f-74e6-4329-bedd-abf93a76c9e8.lance
[2023-12-04T17:36:55Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf] Loaded 10000000 rows of precomputed partitions
[2023-12-04T17:36:55Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf::builder] Building IVF shuffler
[2023-12-04T17:37:23Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf::builder] IVF shuffler built
[2023-12-04T17:47:04Z INFO  lance::index::vector::ivf] Built IVF partitions: 608.89886s
```

title: chore: add shortcuts for creating arrow types
body:
I've been mildly annoyed at times with the readability of creating arrow schemas / batches (mostly in unit tests).  For fun, I played around a little with macros to see if I could improve the experience and this is what I came up with.  This can replace code that looks like this:

```
let schema = Schema::new(vec![
    Field::new("x", DataType::UInt8, true),
    Field::new("y", DataType::UInt16, true),
    Field::new("strings", DataType::Utf8, true),
]);
let batch = RecordBatch::try_new(
    Arc::new(schema),
    vec![
        Arc::new(UInt8Array::from_iter(&[Some(1), Some(2), None])),
        Arc::new(UInt16Array::from_iter(&[Some(4), None, Some(5)])),
        Arc::new(StringArray::from_iter(&[None, Some("x"), Some("y")])),
    ],
)
.unwrap();
```

with code that looks like this:

```
let batch = arr_batch!({
    x: [1, 2, ()] as u8,
    y: [4, (), 5] as u16,
    strings: [(), "x", "y"] as &str,
});
```

There are five macros, `arr_type, arr_field, arr_schema, arr_array, arr_batch`.  For more examples of each of these take a look at the unit tests in the `arrow_shortcuts` crate.

This isn't yet complete.  There are a few MVP features I think would be needed (and will be needed if we want to replace existing code):

 * Better support for declaring types as nullable
 * Ability to specify large string / large binary
 * Ability for `arr_array` to create arrays of arrays (e.g. `arr_array!([[1, 2], [3, ()]] as [u32; 2])`

Drafting this at the moment to see if there is any interest before I put more work into finishing it off.

title: chore: add new python benchmarks for testing scalar indices
body: There is also some new tracing and a utility for tracing streams.

title: Cache the result of `read_manifest_indexes`
body:
This should have some improvement on scalar index performance, especially those that hit multiple indices.  It should be pretty straightforward to cache too.  We can invalidate it whenever the manifest changes.

If, for some reason, this is too tricky, then we could also rework the scalar index search so it isn't so reliant on this function but that would increase complexity of the scalar index code so caching seems simpler.

title: perf: add type coersion for in-list expressions
body:
this is important for enabling scalar indices to work properly on filters that contain in-list expressions

closes #1641

title: chore: add rust benchmarks for scalar indices
body: This focuses on the CPU side of the benchmarks.  It does confirm that a chain of equalities (`X != 0 AND x != ...`) is faster than a `NOT IN` statement but, even so, the slowest cases are still well under 1ms.  The only situations that are considerably slower are the ones that have to process 10's of pages of data.  So these do not give a convincing explanation for the timing I was seeing in #1641

title: fix: prevent OOM when IVF centroids are provided
body:
These are a small collection of fixes I needed in order to run a benchmark for partitioning while using CUDA acceleration.

1. Regardless of whether IVF is going to be trained, we load in enough vectors to do the training. This causes OOM on large datasets, so I've changed this to skip loading those vectors if the IVF centroids have already been passed in. GPU training can handle larger than memory datasets thanks to it's data loader, so this makes large scale training with GPUs possible.
2. Added some cast to ints, as it's easy to accidentally get floats in some cases.
3. Handle older pyarrow versions in GPU training API

title: perf: add a fast path for converting bytes into array when the bytes has the correct alignment
body:
Add a branch when conversion bytes from file into arrow arrays. In this new branch, we check if the pointer to the bytes alignments with the target datatype. If they align, we convert the pointer into arrow buffer directly without copy.

benchmark, the effect is fairly significant when nprobes is set to a large number
```
Flat_Index(d=128,top_k=10,nprobes=10)
                        time:   [1.1026 ms 1.1167 ms 1.1326 ms]
                        change: [-4.7828% -0.4776% +3.8902%] (p = 0.85 > 0.10)
                        No change in performance detected.

Ivf_PQ_Refine(d=128,top_k=10,nprobes=10, refine=2)
                        time:   [1.2022 ms 1.2143 ms 1.2330 ms]
                        change: [-7.9295% -5.5750% -3.4885%] (p = 0.00 < 0.10)
                        Performance has improved.

Ivf_PQ_NoCache(d=128,top_k=10,nprobes=32, refine=1)
                        time:   [4.2582 ms 4.2736 ms 4.2869 ms]
                        change: [-28.852% -27.749% -26.565%] (p = 0.00 < 0.10)
                        Performance has improved.
```

title: feat: add "merge insert" operation based on merge operation in other databases
body: The "merge insert" operation can insert new rows, delete old rows, and update old rows, all in a single transaction.  It is a generic operation that is used to provide upsert, find-or-create, and "replace range".

title: fix: correctly avg centroids in update logic in GPU IVF training
body: we forgot to divide the sum of the vectors by the count. this PR fixes that

title: perf: use datafusion to shuffle index partition data
body:
This removes the current `Shuffler` in favor of using DataFusion to sort the index data into partitions. DataFusion supports spilling to disk while sorting larger-than-memory data, but will keep the data in memory if it can fit. In theory this can achieve good performance when we need to shuffle the data.

To keep this to a small refactor, I've only replaced the shuffler. However, we could expand the role of DataFusion further by having the partition ID assignment and PQ transformations written in terms of DataFusion's DataFrame API.

Closes #1483

title: test: fix for test
body:
I don't think this has any user impact. For the purposes of our code an empty bitmap is the same as a missing entry.

Also retroactively addressing https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/1632#discussion_r1398274919

title: feat: null support for plain encoding
body:
Subtask of #16.

Create proposal for nullability implementation with a mini batch binary mask.

title: Scalar index performance for `x NOT IN (0)` is considerably worse than `x != 0`
body: Also, if there are multiple values, (e.g. `x NOT IN (0, 1)`) then it appears that `x != 0 && x != 1` is still faster.  It's possible there is a cutoff somewhere (e.g. I believe `NOT IN` is using a hashmap for the value set which is probably faster once the value set is sufficiently large) or it is possible there is a bug.  Either way we should be able to ensure the scalar index performs well with small value sets.

title: perf: fast L2 distance table build
body: Use avx512/avx2 gather instruction for L2 distance table building.

title: feat: index cache size should be settable and readable in bytes
body: See #1613 and https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/1587#discussion_r1395073493

title: feat: experimental GPU support for IVF partiton routing in native rust
chore: upgrade datafusion to 33.0
Regression: no-op filters will now fail
body: Previously, we didn't support `dataset.delete("true")`, so as a workaround we would use no-op filters like `dataset.delete("vector IS NOT NULL")`. However, recently we added predicate optimization, so if `vector` is not a nullable column then `vector IS NOT NULL` will be simplified to `true` and we hit the same bug as earlier. We need to change the short-circuit logic to happen after the predicate optimization step.

title: chore: make lance-linalg benchmark ready to test bf16 data

* Allow `generate_random_data` to create random array for bf16, f16, f32, f64
* Fix `BFloat16Array.as_slice()`
* Change cosine benchmark to support multiple data types

title: High ANN search latency after deleting a full fragment
body:
``` (py311) ➜ safeToShare rm -rf test.lance && python test.py creating table appending appending creating index testing query 3 query took 0.02812970895320177 seconds delete a fragement testing query 3 query took 3.713116083992645 seconds ```
Reproduction

```python import lance import pyarrow as pa import lancedb import uuid import random import time def test_query(): ds = lance.dataset("test.lance") start = time.perf_counter() for _ in range(3): query = [random.random() for _ in range(128)] ds.to_table(nearest={ "column": "vector", "q": query, "use_index": True }) print(f"3 query took {time.perf_counter() - start} seconds") def schema(): return pa.schema([ pa.field('id', pa.string()), pa.field('vector', lancedb.schema.vector(128)), ]) def random_row(): return { 'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'vector': [random.random() for _ in range(128)], } def random_table(n): return pa.Table.from_pylist([random_row() for _ in range(n)], schema=schema()) print("creating table") lance.write_dataset(random_table(0), "test.lance") print("appending") lance.write_dataset(random_table(512), "test.lance", mode="append") print("appending") second_append = random_table(2) lance.write_dataset(second_append, "test.lance", mode="append") print("creating index") ds = lance.dataset("test.lance") ds.create_index("vector", "IVF_PQ", metric="L2", num_partitions=1, num_sub_vectors=16) print("testing query") test_query() print("delete a fragement") ids_to_delete = second_append["id"].to_pylist() quoted_ids = ", ".join([f'"{id}"' for id in ids_to_delete]) ds = lance.dataset("test.lance") ds.delete(f"`id` IN ({quoted_ids})") print("testing query") test_query() ```

title: perf: more efficient treemap implementation for row ids
body:
Provides our own TreeMap implementation, which is optimized for the case where an entire fragment is added. When a full fragment is to be marked, we use `None` instead of a full `RoaringBitmap`.

Fixes #1633

title: test: verifed that fp16 works on kmean training using torch gpu
body: Add tests to verify that the GPU kmean training can work with fp16 and fp64 data types.

title: feat(rust): simplify object store option API
body:
#1547 added and removed some APIs. This PR brings back some APIs that we still need,
and deprecates some APIs that were made redundant.

title: chore: expose avx512fp16 feature via main lance crate
body:
`lance-linalg` has a feature flag `avx512fp16`, once enabled, it compiles the `f16.c` for auto-vectorized routines for `f16` on CPUs with `avx512fp16` instruction set.

This PR propagate the optional feature flag (avx512fp16) to the lance crate, so that we can build `avx512fp16` from the main crate as well.

Did not use `RUSTCFLAGS="-C target-feature=+avx512fp16" because rustc (`1.74` at the time of wriitng), does not pass this feature to `build.rs` .

title: feat: make partition calculation parallel
body: make IVF partition calculation parallelize

title: feat: serialize arbitrary float type of PQ to protobuf
ci: use M1 runner for now for release
body: Workaround until we find a proper fix for #1621.

title: chore: expose index cache hit rate in python
body: This is a leftover task from #1586

title: Cross compilation broken by C code for MacOS
body:
We currently cross-compile for M1 MacOS wheels, but this produced an invalid wheel for the last release. We had to manually build on M1 locally to get a working wheel.

I've confirmed that this issue does not happen if we remove the use of the C code:

https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/main/rust/lance-linalg/src/simd/f16.c

We will need to figure out why cross compilation is failing.

For the time being, as a temporary fix we can switch the the M1 runner. But in the long term I think it's important we support cross compilation of our crate.

title: chore: minor changes to tracing instrumentation
body: These are pretty minor fixes but I am trying to make sure that all the spans we have are debug level except for those at the dataset/scanner layer (which are info).  Then, I am trying to make sure that all of our debug scans always roll up to one of the info spans.  This generates better traces as there are fewer (and more meaningful) root spans.
